title: Parts of Speech
introduction: Parts of speech classify words based on their function in a sentence. There are eight primary parts of speech.

content.value: A noun is a word that names a person, place, or thing.
Types of Noun:

items: Proper Noun – Specific names, places, or things. (e.g., John, India, Microsoft).
Common Noun – General names for places or things. (e.g., boy, girl, city, animal, book).
Material Noun – Things made from materials that can be seen or touched (e.g., gold, silver, cotton, wood).
Abstract Noun – Ideas, feelings, or emotions (e.g., happiness, bravery, honesty, fear, love, corruption).
Collective Noun – A collective noun is a word that refers to a group of people, animals, or things, treating them as a single unit

content.heading: Collective Nouns Categories:
items: Countable Noun – Groups of people, things, or animals (e.g., team, a dozen eggs).
Uncountable Noun – Noun that cannot be counted (e.g., water, air).

content.value: Pronouns are words used in place of nouns.
Examples: he, she, it, they, this, that.
Types of Pronoun:

items: Personal Pronoun – I, you, he, she, we, they (e.g., He/She is a nice person).
Possessive Pronoun – mine, yours, his, hers (e.g., This book is mine, this is his bike).
Reflexive Pronoun – myself, himself, herself, itself, themselves.
Relative Pronoun – who, which, that, whom.
Demonstrative Pronoun – this, that, these, those.
Indefinite Pronoun – do not refer to any specific individual (e.g., anyone, something, someone).

content.value: A verb describes what the subject of a sentence is doing.
Types of Verbs:

items: Action Verbs – Show actions (e.g., run, eat, write, sleep).
Auxiliary Verbs (Helping Verbs) – am, is, are, was, were, has, have, had, be, do (e.g., She is reading).
Modal Verbs – Indicate possibility or necessity (e.g., can, could, may, might, will, would, must, should).

content.value: An adjective is a word that modifies or describes a noun or pronoun
Examples: beautiful, smart, small, happy, nice, good, ugly.
Types of Adjectives:

items: Descriptive Adjectives – Describe qualities (e.g., tall, smart, intelligent).
Comparative Adjectives – Compare two entities (e.g., taller, smarter, smaller).
Superlative Adjectives – Indicate the extreme or highest degree (e.g., tallest, smartest, smallest).
Numerical Adjectives – Indicate numbers (e.g., one, two, three).

content.value: An adverb modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb.
Examples: quickly, very, well, always, fast, here, there.
Types of Adverbs:

items: Manner – Describes how something is done (e.g., she sings beautifully).
Place – Indicates location (e.g., he went outside).
Time – Indicates when something happens (e.g., we will meet tomorrow).
Degree – Indicates intensity (e.g., it is hot today).
Frequency – Describes how often something occurs (e.g., he often comes to my home).

content.value: A preposition shows the relationship between a noun (or pronoun) and other words in a sentence.
Examples: on, in, under, behind, between.
Sentence Example: The book is on the table.
A conjunction connects words, phrases, or clauses.
Types of Conjunctions:

items: Coordinating Conjunctions – and, but, or, nor, yet, so.
Subordinating Conjunctions – because, although, while, if.
Correlative Conjunctions – either…or, neither…nor, both…and.

content.value: An interjection expresses sudden emotion.
Examples: Wow! Ouch! Oh!
Sentence Example: Wow! That's an amazing view!

exercises.title: Identify Parts of Speech
exercises.instructions: Identify the part of speech for each highlighted word in the following sentences.

questions.question: The *beautiful* flowers are in the garden.
